item.title: Text based game in C
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

protips! This is how you can do text colours without using the color command:

#define KNRM  "\x1B[0m"
#define KRED  "\x1B[31m"
#define KGRN  "\x1B[32m"
#define KYEL  "\x1B[33m"
#define KBLU  "\x1B[34m"
#define KMAG  "\x1B[35m"
#define KCYN  "\x1B[36m"
#define KWHT  "\x1B[37m"

int main()
{
    printf("%sred\n", KRED);
    printf("%sgreen\n", KGRN);
    printf("%syellow\n", KYEL);
    printf("%sblue\n", KBLU);
    printf("%smagenta\n", KMAG);
    printf("%scyan\n", KCYN);
    printf("%swhite\n", KWHT);
    printf("%snormal\n", KNRM);

    return 0;
}

and the system(“exit”); can just be replaced with exit(EXIT_SUCCESS); like you’re already doing !

do something about your nasty useless platform-dependent system() calls. you might as well in the process make the program entirely cross-platform (which isn’t hard, but if you really want a direct replacement to getch() you should look at ncurses although that is prolly overkill for your game). also don’t return int if you aren’t ever going to use it. join your printf calls; you’re only using string literals (“as” “df”).

item.title: Text based game in C
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

It’s just a .h file containing the function prototypes (the function definitions you have near the top) for implementations defined in a .c file. Header files let you do cool stuff like compiling against an interface rather than the entire implementation, speeding up compilation and making it more modular etc. It’s also nice to open up a header file when you’re looking at someone else’s code or using a library because you usually don’t care about how stuff works - you just want to know what the functions are.

This is a pretty complete example of how to write a nice header file: http://stackoverflow.com/a/2831379/366133
